review_blob: A perfect lager. Fresh, clean, crisp, golden, just enough hops and no funky skunkiness. Killer with fish.
Creamy white head, hazy golden-orange color, aroma of bananas, light hop taste, rich smooth body for a hefe. Paired well with bulgogi marinated beef kabobs.
Really nice balance of stone fruit, light tartness, and a chalky dryness, and unexpected lack of Belgian ale yeast.
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - Tank 7 Farmhouse Ale

review_blob: Crisp, fresh, delicious. Tastes of apples, a little citrus, and champagne, a little sweet, a little tartness. Very nice.

This beer worked well for me as an accompaniment to my salad. The aroma and taste held hints of pear, and a clean smooth palate with no funky maltiness, made it work well with light food, and in this case better than a wheat beer would have and it was a nice change from the usual options when I want something lighter flavored to begin my meal. It has a touch of sweetness, too, which made for a really good follower to a spicy dish such as the blackened fish that I had.

Im really enjoying this beer in the heat of summer. It has a smooth and refreshing mouthfeel with a hint of sweetness that floods over the tongue and down the throat and before you know it, it is gone and you are reaching for the next bottle.

Aroma of citrus, bitter orange, peach, and cherry, with pine. Classic deep clear amber color with a light, lacey head. Medium sweet, touch of sour, salt, and strong bitter finish. Full body, lively carbonation, sticky creamy, with a long, piney bitter finish. Theres a lot going on here. Like a complicated woman who is hot and sweet and salty and makes you want to slap her.

Aroma of earthy hay, ripe pineapple and dried apricot.
Golden copper color with a lively, frothy head. Slightly hazy.
Taste of sweet apricot, pineapple, some pine, just a light bitterness and light sourness.
Carbonation both soft and lively, a sublime experience crossing the lips and tongue. Creamy texture. Finish is moderate bitter.

Bottle Date Code: 2 5622:14
Drank 8/3/2012
beer_name: Sierra Nevada / Russian River BRUX Domesticated Wild Ale

review_blob: Aroma of brown bread, chocolate, toast, banana; color opaque brown, thin tan head; light sweetness, light bitter, slight sour; full bodied, creamy, soft carbonation, long, clean finish

Aroma of lemon peel and baguette. Pale golden amber, hazy, thin white head. Medium sweet flavor, light bitter, strong lemon, salty, a hint of almonds and vanilla. Light body, soft carbonation, finish short, clean, and citrusy.

Drank this with grilled halibut, portobellos, and spinach. This beer is an excellent complement to light fish.

Im assuming that this is the same as "Tongue Buckler Imperial Red".

Pours a rich dark red amber with a medium frothy white head. Aroma of spruce, leather, soy sauce, caramel. Taste has a light sweetness, heavy bitter, and a touch of sour. Full body, a little thick, medium carbonation. Finish is long bitter that fades to a clean sweetness.

Overall the bitter hops and alcohol initially overpower the palate, making it somewhat overheated for the medium richness of this red. I would ask for more body and flavor, or a little less hops, to balance this. Perhaps some aging will bring this to nirvana. Some time left resting in the glass improves the balance. As it stands, the excellent finish keeps me sipping this to the end.

Tasting Note: When sampling the aroma, avoid drawing a full clod of the head into the nasal cavity. The carbonation mines the sinuses with astringent submunitions, followed by an explosion of piney darts between the eyes.
beer_name: Ballast Point Tongue Buckler Imperial Red Ale

review_blob: Rich aroma of orange peel, malt, bread, a little pine or rosemary. Appearance is a clear, burnt orange, minimal head that laces on the glass. Somewhat viscous body that slides over the tongue, leaving its rich taste behind to linger in a long finish. Lively but soft carbonation. A nice balance of rich body, slight sweet notes of currant, with an exploding carbonated dry bitterness A long, dry finish turns from slightly sweet to strong, dry bitter, leaving a clean lingering taste that lasts.

beer_brewer_name: Leinenkugel Brewing Company (Tenth & Blake Beer Co.)
review_blob:
Aroma was lightly sweet, bread and citrus. Color is pale, a littly cloudy. Head is a creamy meringue white. Taste is medium sweet, almost no bitter, with honey and blueberry and citrus flavors. Texture is creamy, carbonation is very fine, finish is sweet.

This has become my favorite beer to cool off after a hot day or a hot workout.
Palate wasnt smooth as I like from a wheat beer, bubbles were large, it was dry on the tongue and only moderately refreshing, and the taste was rather bland. It tasted like dry wheat.
Creamy, soft pillowy mouthfeel combines with the firm bitterness to create a great IPA. Bread dough, toast, and nuts; herbs, citrus peel, and resiny bitterness,

22 oz bottle from BevMo. I was looking for something lighter and fresh today, and the store had it highly rated. This beer looked and smelled good, a nice slightly cloudy wheat beer with a fresh aroma. It tasted thin and soapy, a touch of quinine, and the tangerine flavor tasted artificial. I would have been happy with a combination of light bitterness, pine, and citrus, but instead got tonic water with soap and a tangerine Lifesaver. It did not have the smooth, creamy texture that I look for in a good wheat beer. I knocked over the bottle with 1/3 left and didnt miss it at all. I would have been much happier with a good wheat- or wit-beer with a slice of orange in it. Or next time, maybe a slice of tangerine.

22 oz bottles from a strip mall liquor store that specializes in King Cobra, cigarettes, and porn. This was like drinking a rich double espresso with fresh creme and a piece of 100% chocolate dropped in and perfect squirt of soda fountain carbonation. I could drink that rich creamy body through a straw. Not sure why this isnt a stout. Until now, my favorite stout was Surly Darkness. Surly a little smoother, while 15th has fuller flavor and more bitter. This makes for long lasting finish. I lean towards the flavor and bitter.
beer_name: Stone 15th Anniversary Escondidian Imperial Black IPA

review_blob: A great creamy brown head on top of a smooth, intense, bakers chocolate with delicious mocha undertones. One of the two best stouts I ever had.
